ArticleItem.Title: New Barbie Ad Campaign and Its Powerful Message to Girls
ArticleItem.Summary: When I became a mother to two girls, I became acutely aware of the subtle message so many commercials and toys and clothes were sending to girls.
ArticleItem.ContentText: <p>I&rsquo;m a mom of 2 girls, and I am the CFO at Miller Ad Agency.&nbsp; My mother started this company over 30 years ago.&nbsp; Growing up in the Advertising world, I&rsquo;ve seen (and even cameo-ed in) a LOT of commercials.&nbsp; But when I became a mother to two girls, I became acutely aware of the subtle message so many commercials and toys and clothes were sending to girls.&nbsp; Even today, in 2016, you will still find major advertisers subtly hinting that men make the money &ndash; women do the homemaking.&nbsp; Now, that is all fine and good for whoever chooses to run their household that way.&nbsp; Women are free to do anything in America, including stay home and run the household, and I have many amazingly brilliant friends who choose to do just that.&nbsp; I&rsquo;ll also be very proud of my girls if that is the path they choose to take.&nbsp; But in the photo-shop, Kardashian world we live in, I want to be very sure that they know girls can do ANYTHING.&nbsp; Which is why I am so thrilled with Barbie&rsquo;s new campaign.&nbsp; As some of you may remember, Barbie ran into quite the controversy (rightly so, in my opinion), with their &ldquo;Math is hard.&nbsp; Shopping&rsquo;s fun!&rdquo; talking Barbie.&nbsp; Good grief.&nbsp; Definitely not the message I want my daughters to hear.&nbsp; (Shopping IS fun, but so is math.)&nbsp; But they have worked hard to repair their reputation with their new campaign &ldquo;Imagine the Possibilities&rdquo;.&nbsp; If you haven&rsquo;t seen it, it shows young girls pretending to be professors, veterinarians, business women.&nbsp; Is this commercial for kids? No.&nbsp; It is for the adults who buy the barbies.&nbsp; It is to convince us (especially moms) that Barbie is more than an impossibly tall, thin blonde who runs around after Ken.&nbsp; She is anything you want her to be.&nbsp; Bravo Barbie.&nbsp; You have won a fan back by listening to your customers, even if it took you a while.&nbsp;</p>

ArticleItem.Title: Find your Voice, Find the Future
ArticleItem.Summary: There’s more to auto dealer advertising than screaming commercials.
ArticleItem.ContentText:
<p>There&rsquo;s more to auto dealer advertising than screaming commercials. Unfortunately when sales slow down, hard sell advertising normally kicks in giving the dealer a quick boost in sales. Finding a balance between the immediate gratification of hard sell advertising and long term branding is difficult for most dealers. Which is understandable when you&rsquo;re looking at your monthly expenses versus your monthly gross profit, but branding your dealership is the only way to build for the future?</p>
<p>The future success start with finding your voice, a voice that reflects the personality of your dealership. Are you hard sale all the time, do you follow all the rules, do you like taking chances, is customer satisfaction really important to you? Didn&rsquo;t know your dealership had a personality? Your customer and former customers assign personality traits to your dealership. Trustworthy, Caring, Crooks, High Pressure, Fair&hellip;. So start defining your dealership&rsquo;s personality and from that a branding voice will emerge that can carry your advertising message today and in the future.</p>

ArticleItem.Title: Taking a Perceived Problem and Making into an Outstanding Commercial
ArticleItem.Summary: Apple knew they had a perception problem when it came to their new AirPods and the take away of the earphone jack on the new iPhone 7. So what did Apple do?
ArticleItem.ContentText: <p>Apple knew they had a perception problem when it came to their new AirPods and the take away of the earphone jack on the new iPhone 7.&nbsp; People worried the earbuds would fall out.&nbsp; So what did Apple do?&nbsp; Did they do an infomercial explaining how they tested the AirPods?&nbsp; Provide boring statistics about their success?&nbsp; Of course not.&nbsp; Apple prides itself on being cool &ndash; on being sexy.&nbsp; So they created one of the most interesting, cool and sexy ads I have seen in quite a while.&nbsp; There is no voice-over.&nbsp; Minimal graphics on the screen.&nbsp; Just an upbeat song with a dancer doing gravity-defying dance moves while wearing his Airpods &ndash; which of course, never fall out.&nbsp; The commercial is true brilliance because first &ndash; my husband and I watched every second of it.&nbsp; It was so visually and acoustically appealing, we wanted to watch from beginning to end.&nbsp; Second, it proved the point that AirPods are actually even better than older versions of earbuds because of the freedom they provide.&nbsp; Third, it made theAirPods seem cool and sexy.&nbsp; I want those earbuds, and I don&rsquo;t even use earbuds.&nbsp; Quite a lot accomplished in 60 seconds.&nbsp; Bravo, Apple.&nbsp;</p>
